This is a replacement for the plastic mount for the duct fan on the left side of a Replicator2 extruder.  It is a direct bolt on replacement which should be stronger than the stock mount.  It also holds the cable bundle much more securely than the stock part.  There is a hole for a small zip-tie to pass through and positively secure the cable.  
I printed it out at 50% fill and it took an hour.  
v2 file does not require rafts or supports so there is no cleanup.  Just print with the face that mates with the fan on the platform and then install!  
The version with "No Tube Holder" is only for a cleaner look and better access if you have an extruder which has a guide tube holder built in (3in1 Universal Extruder Upgrade shown).

I sliced this model using the latest Makerware.  I used PLA on the high quality setting (5 shells, 20% fill, no rafts/supports).  Place the fan mounting surface on the platform and print and install.  
Having the guide tube mount removed (because it is present on the extruder) is a huge time savings when you have a clog.  You can unbolt the extruder and slide it up the filament without having to unload.  Also, it gives clear access to the thermal barrier tube if you need to remove burnt material with a toothpick/drill bit by and.  Also, if you rotate the stepper motor so the wiring connector is towards the left side, it is a much cleaner look... very neat and tidy.

author: larkin

description.text:
I wanted to create a printable part that could take the place of the plywood that makes up the CupCakeCNC. I chose to make a repeating pattern of interlocking puzzle pieces. However, a single layer of these puzzle pieces would not be strong enough for anything but a toy. I added a set of holes that would allow offset layers of puzzle pieces to be bolted together, forming a stronger whole. I expect to be starting into making corner and edge pieces. I think it would be possible to laser cut these. The current version is 40mm x 40mm x 4mm corner-to-corner-to-corner. Tongue-to-tongue it is 60mm. The holes are 4mm in diameter and spaced 20mm apart. Earlier attempts at 60mm x 60mm x 5mm pieces all had to be aborted due to head crashes with ABS shrinkage curling up the corners and breaking the raft from the build surface or, in one case curling up the entire acrylic build surface. This might have been due to the use of an Infill Solidity (ratio) of 1.0 This was created in Art of Illusion. Here is a breakdown of the objects in the .aoi
file: Camera 1 and Light 1 were just left in there Puzzle_Curve_No_Clearance is the basic outline of the puzzle piece and does not have any adjustments for the clearance that will be needed for the tongue parts to fit in the mouth parts. It is an approximating curve. The corners are created with three overlapping points. Curve 1 and its children, Curve 1, Curve 1, and Curve 1 are curves to give an indication of where the holes would be located when I was working with Puzzle_Curve_No_Clearance. The first Puzzle_Curve_With_Clearance is a modification of Puzzle_Curve_No_Clearance where the tongues are decreased in size. You can see the changes by making visible only Puzzle_Curve_No_Clearance and the first Puzzle_Curve_With_Clearance. The points were offset by 0.25units. The second Puzzle_Curve_With_Clearance is a triangle mesh of the first Puzzle_Curve_With_Clearance. The Puzzle_Piece_With_Holes is the final object that was used for .stl output. It is made of Puzzle_Piece, a 4-unit extrusion of the Puzzle_Curve_With_Clearance triangle mesh. and a CSG union of four 8-unit long cylinders that are subtracted (CSG difference) from Puzzle_Piece to form the drill holes in the final object. The .gcode file uses a hexagonal fill and takes about 16 minutes to print on a CupCakeCNC. The file was created with an Infill Solidity (ratio) of 0.32. The hex_fill.zip file contains the contents of the .skeinforge directory used in Skeinforge to make the hexagonal fill parts seen in the images and used in the .gcode file.

Put the pieces together like a puzzle, there is no wrong way, the 'tongues' fit into the 'mouths.'  For a two layer setup, one layer will be offset from the other layer such that the holes of a piece in one layer will align with the holes of four separate pieces in the other layer.  M3 nuts and bolts and optionally, washers will hold the two layers together.
See the pictures for further details.

comments.author: Tinykiwi

comments.text: I think the non printed moves speed is key but there are a couple of other tweaks that you might try. Firstly, looks like you are over extruding, measure your filament with a vernier caliper and set that size - mine came out as 1.65mm so I adjusted it and have had much better prints since. Secondly, have you got a cooling fan blowing on the completed print? I set up an old PC 5inch fan and its incredible how far you can bridge once you have it and you don't get the stringy bits which some of your pictures show.
comments.author: philwaud

comments.text:
What I would do is turn you printer on, and move either you x or y axis like 10 mm. After this try and lightly push on either your bed or your x carriage depending on what you chose. If what you push on makes a sort of clicking sounds and "skips steps" then increase the current by adjusting the pots on your board. If it doesn't I would then check your E steps per mm settings again.
two videos that will help with the processes respectively.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bItYRMLGoVc&list=PLDJMid0lOOYnRCAdbFfzECor3EbqF8euw&index=4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VIHgDiCCY0Y

comments.text:
Looks like a motion/vibration and retraction issues to me.
On my prusa my belts are set so they 'twang' if you 'pluck' them. They wernt but after the adjustment my layers are perfectly in line.
Is your x axis level?
As for the retraction, try making it a little more aggressive in the sense that a shorter movement is needed for retraction to occur.

comments.author: Brad0315

comments.text:
I agree with Shankman and Portamaker3D, It looks like the printer is having issues keeping position.
One easy check is to jog the extruder to the center build area and try and push the the extruder around by the nozzle in the X/Y direction and see if you can detect any excessive moment/slop in the system. Make sure the nozzle is cold :D
Check any pulley grub screws, if the grub screw is loose on the motor shaft it can move slightly on the flat area of the shaft creating registration errors.
I have never used the bot you have (assuming its a Sunhokey Prusa) but unless your acceleration is limiting it effectively the 800mm/s travel speed is crazy fast. It could be losing steps because of that but that kind of issues normally shows up as larger X-Y miss alignments then what you have.
comments.author: Kezat

comments.text: Could be loose belt or glass as already stated could also be poor firmware configuration or driver pots turned up to high or drivers overheating causing stepper motor to skip more information on machine firmware etc would be required for anyone to give meaningful advice. Is it a new machine? New firmware? Which firmware? Axis with problems is it belt or screw? How well calibrated is printer?
comments.author: Lucan07

comments.text: Lucan as far as pots, I'm using DRV8825's on all steppers.  I have each one set to about .75v.  All my Axis have been calibrated and steps corrected.  My X and Y are using belts and the Z is a dual 8mm screw.  I'm using Arduino 1.6.5 with Marlin.  I'm using the stock firmware from Sunhokey with a few minor changes to steps, LCD, turning on EEPROM and Auto Bed Leveling.  If anything with my calibration is wrong it is with the Extruder.  I've tried and tried to get it zeroed in but I can't.  I've used Zennmaster's recommendation, and Tom's also as well as a few others on YouTube.
comments.author: Lucan07

comments.text: Not sure what your on about with extruder but look at reprap.org for pid tuning. Steppers can skip if drivers get warm check cooling and not buried under excess wires stopping cooling, also if your heating the bed the power supply may be struggling if under powered could cause skips on stepper try printing on cold bed with pla
comments.author: Brad0315

comments.text: Take a look at this troubleshooting guide. http://reprap.org/wiki/Print_Troubleshooting_Pictorial_Guide I have found it to very helpful in cases like this. In my opinion it looks like the bed temperature may be too hot. That can cause what appears to be a shrinkage effect at the bottom of the print.

My glass on the bed is held down with clamps on each corner.  They are as stiff or more than the bulldog clips.  Not saying that I'm correct, but I'm not sure how to tell for sure.  Thanks for replying!
comments.author: CertifiedNerd

comments.text: I just remembered some other causes for this misalignment that I have experienced. Way back when I built my Prusa i2 the nozzle would occasionally catch on something on the print and cause the axis to skip steps. My solution was to increase current to steppers and use z- retraction of .2mm for travel moves. I loose bed (heat bead screws actually), worn bearings, z-wobble, loose belts, and motor under current are all issues I have troubleshooted that caused layer misalignment. It appears that only one axis has severe misalignment and it is consistent along the other. This hints to me that you are either over working your stepper drivers or need to turn up the current adjustment for your stepper drivers. I would look for instructions on adjusting stepper current with whatever board you have.
comments.author: Brad0315

comments.text:
I rebuilt my sunhokey 2015 completely as its a hunk of crud l. Cheap acrylic. Supplier wont supply all spares - only sigular parts on request which take about a week to receive.
I had the same ussue and i ended up strengthening the whole frame - but the main solution was a new style of z threaded rod holder at the top with a bearing to hold it still. Now i get perfectly straight sides on my prints.
I am interested in modifying my firmware also - mainly to activate eeprom. Maybe we could exchange tips?

comments.text: im looking at a plug at the end of the exhaust even if it lets a smaller amount of exhaust out it is creating more back pressure this is bad. when we race we take off the pipes to let out more giving us way more horsepower. if i close mine even a little due to the race cam it will die. i use a 3300 stall to let it idle but its the same weather stock or built. a true good silencer should have many holes as to not create more pressure. take a jetski for example if there's a small leak under the seat of exhaust it wont even run. this is why racers use straight open pipes. you need to release the pressure in alot of small holes or it can cause internal damage also. been there done that. very important to keep it running smoothly. a old trick was to stick a banana in the tail pipe then the car won't run long and they think it's broken then you offer them cash for it. old old scam. take it back out and sell it for a profit. seen it done as a small boy. kool idea just put a ton of holes in it see how well it works don't plug it like this.imho

A propello polyhedra ornament - see thing:1116532 and thing:1119768. D.I. McCooey has described a number of propello polyhedra on his "Visual Polyhedra" web site - http://dmccooey.com/polyhedra/ - This example is an attractive one with 3 bands of 4 sided faces that swirl around pentagons and hexagons. McCooey calls it an Expanded Propello Truncated Icosahedron (canonical). http://dmccooey.com/polyhedra/ExpandedPropelloTruncatedIcosahedron.html Coordinates and faces were downloaded from McCooney's site and used to make two ornaments: a wire frame and a wire frame with pentagonal and hexagonal faces.

title: LOC - NAR from the Movie HEAVY METAL

description.text:
This is a model and holder for the LOC - NAR from the animated movie HEAVY METAL. I originally created this as a holder for my iPhone 4S and that is what the blender file I included is for (The base is a little different in the blender file). I wasn't super happy with the angle of the holder and I wanted to add a charger for the iPhone too. But I never got around to it so I thought I might as well share it with everyone on Thingiverse, someone might get a kick out of it and of course do their own Remix too. The idea of creating the LOC-NAR came because I had this super bright green filament and I thought I'd make something neat out of it and it just came to me. I suggest printing the separate stl files in the appropriate colours and gluing them together, except for the LOC-NAR itself as anyone who has seen the movie know it can't be contained. Have fun,
Nowhereman999

comments.text: If you want to avoid having very long antenna tubes, the antenna wire can be wrapped around the uprights twice then put through the tubes. That will give you about 3.5cm. As long as the exposed part of the antenna is out you are good to go. The ideal is to maintain 90 deg separation for diversity and best long distance signal. For the 250 class this is not critical since most flying will be within 500m. No need to have long antenna tubes friends. Will post and update when I'm done signal tests.

When the Dual extruder finally came out for the Taz4, I quickly realized that it was lacking a way to cool the cooling fins and the print. I've seen setups that have fans on each side but it was too bulky adding to the already bulky design. Since there was no good solution in sight, I had to come up with my own solution. The best solution was to design a whole new dual extruder; one with less mass preferably but lets not reinvent the wheel. I simply don't have time for that. The next best solution is to modify the hell out of it. There are a lot of files here. I will list all the parts and provide links to the vendors. Thanks to Lulzbot's open source policy, I can use and modify their files. However, most of the files are designed from scratch. You can find the original file from Lulzbot here: http://devel.lulzbot.com/TAZ/accessories/dual_extruder/dual_extruder-1.0/
and here:
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/ Be advised that the hotend fan has to be constantly on while the hotends are heated otherwise the dual extruder will risk a meltdown. All materials are printed out of ABS unless specified otherwise. The file, Hose coupling, is printed out of Ninja Flex. 1) Hose coupling ABS
This piece connects the ribbed hose to middle hose of the duct work. 2) Air Divider
This piece is super glued on the bottom of the flex plate 3) 12mm to 8mm splitter
This piece divides the ribbed hose into two smaller silicone hoses 4) Hose Holder
Optional 5) Mount Plate 02
Modified with an extra notch in the middle to accommodate the air hoses
Hardware:
  • M3 brass insert (4)
    • 6) Bottom Rack
    Modified with channels for wires and slots for LEDs.
    Electronics:
  • Adafruit LED Sequins - Warm White
    www.adafruit.com/products/1758
    • 7) X-Carriage 01
    Modified to accommodate the extra air hoses
    Hardware:
  • M3 brass insert (15)
    • 8)DEFP Jig 02
    Used to form the copper pipes into shape.
    Instructions:
  • find a blunt long metal object (Metal peg from my peg board; round the end for good results)
  • Insert peg into copper pipe and bend the pipe to the approximate shape.
  • Place pipe into the jig and place the jig into a vice.
  • Squeeze, tap the pipe with hammer to form the desired shape and then remove it from the vice..
  • Tap the jig with a hammer. Do not use excessive force.
  • Cut off the excess pipe that is protruding from the jig.
  • Sand as necessary
    • 9) Hose coupling (Ninja Flex) (4)
    Used to couple the ribbed hose to the dual extruder air duct assembly. It is printed out of Ninja Flex. 10) Dual Extruder Flex Plate
    Modified to direct air to the cooling fins and print.
    Hardware:
  • M3 brass insert (4)
  • Metric set screws, allen, cup point, 3mm x 0.5mm x 6mm (4)
    Vendor: BoltDepot.com
    • 11) Duct Work 07
    Direct air from the hoses to the flex plate.
    Hardware:
    M3 screw 8mm (4) 12) Fan Plate 27
    This is where the fans, knobs, and switch is mounted. I've tried printing the fonts out but found out the resolution was too low for fonts. I've decided to use my CNC router to V-carve the words in and then spray paint it white. If you want the STL file with the fonts in it, let me know, I'll upload the files.

author: StevenTodd

title: Arcade Twist Button Dial for MAME games

description.text: This is a 3-in-one button dial that allows a player to use one hand to control both left/right rotation of a turret or arm as it is twisted accordingly... and also fires if you press it down. This short video shows assembly and action: https://youtu.be/I34hM2YKkFE This is not a quadrature-encoded spinner nor an 8-directional knob! It is simply a bipolar toggle dial with a push button action built in as well. Ideal for MAME versions of Ikari Warriors, Tron and many others. The hole that this fits in is a little smaller than your standard 1 1/8" (29.5mm) hole for arcade machines... it can fit between 24mm and 27mm holes (I only work in metric...) The Housing is the only piece that needs to be printed with external support. The rest just prints on the base plate without any kind of raft/support. Enjoy and I'd love to hear your feedback! Nov 18th, 2015 update: Added shim.stl for adjusting to a 1 1/8" hole. You'll need one for the topside and the underside of the control panel.

This is an archer figure I made to act as my rogue in D&D. It is bland and there are very little accessories, so feel free to change it up however. For the archer I printed, I used a black fabric to make a cape and hood - which is why its not very detailed. There are a few mistakes (maybe more than a few) as far as proportions of things (and beyond), but I tried to make the archer form as accurate as possible. Couldn't design a decent head, so I used one from meshmixer. Enjoy!

title: Tie Fighter Body for Hubsan X4 H107L
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: UPDATE 3: Created camera specific version for H107C: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242547 UPDATE 2: More detailed assembly instructions: http://www.cuddleburrito.com/blog/2015/12/5/tie-fighter-conversion UPDATE: Fixed "arm - FLAT BOTTOM.stl" to be flat on print side.

Have a ready to fly unit made for you or contact us if you need just the 3D printed parts: https://www.etsy.com/shop/cuddleburrito Alternate body for Hubsan X4 quadcopter H107L, but 8.5mm motor mounts included too. Maiden flight:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-rTUFCi0W_c Painted flight:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S5C8o7WFAzw CAD available for editing here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/6a10f46f9e8b44159a9dab73/w/25197f1e32f249cb87d83d67/e/6d5e5fe625fd4aa2b4b7a19f Print Parts:
  • 2 x hull - shell print settings
  • 2 x arm - shell print settings
  • 4 x motor mount - shell print settings
  • 2 x motor arm - shell print settings
  • 2 x wing - 0.15mm layer thickness, solid print settings
    • Notes:
  • Use wire snips to remove extraneous material inside hull. It's a tight fit on purpose, remove and chisel away only what's necessary.
  • Once the circuit is snugly in place, I added small dabs from a hot glue gun to 2 sides of circuit board
  • Two layers of kapton tape ( http://amzn.to/1SyHXu6 ) separates the circuit board from battery.
  • Use the screws that hold the circuit board in a stock Hubsan X4 to fasten the two hull halves together.
  • Drill small holes in the motor arms to thread the motor wires through
  • The stock motor wires aren't long enough to thread through the arms, so I extended them with wires cut from the x4 part replacement kit
    • Designed by:
    http://www.cuddleburrito.com

description.text: I wanted some curved, sloping dividers for my mini drawers so I could put lots of varieties of little screws and stuff in there and still be able to pluck them out easily. This design achieves that by basically printing a sine wave. Some extra math is thrown in to flatten out the bottom of the bins in a configurable way. Thanks to polymaker's 2D graphing library for making this design quick and easy to make.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Silver

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Unless you're making some crazy thick dividers, set infill to zero and your slicer's walls to one nozzle-width. Set the thickness in the customizer to three times your nozzle width. That way the printer will just gracefully outline the form over and over, instead of making a ton of tiny little infills that end up as strings and boogers all over your print.

comments.text: good idea, but why make them curved? Why not just make them straight that way you don't have any wasted space?

description.text: Got the idea of a knife from the new movie trailer "Deadpool". So pumped up for the movie.

This is a player screen I made for the Medina game pieces at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943076 The roof and walls use 3 magnets each (0.8mm diameter, 1mm thick) to attach right now. I really like the magnetic attachment, but feel free to modify it for a peg or something if you prefer. You don't even need to glue them in place, I just put some ABS slurry over the top and when it dries it leaves the magnet under a very thin coat of abs. The hinges on the walls are print in place. If you have problems with the inner hinge not sticking to the bed enough, try printing it with a brim. This will lock the lower layer of the hinge in place, but you can cut it out pretty easily with an exacto knife (see the two before and after underside shots). The hinges on the roof are made to take a 3 mm piece of printer filament. I just cut a piece to size and then heat up a knife in a candle to melt the ends of the filament so it does not slip out of place. Some small bolts/screws would surely work fine as well if you don't have this size filament. I have printed this in both ABS and HIPs. I would suggest ABS personally as it is super easy to fix any splitting with some ABS+acetone slurry. For the least amount of splitting on the main wall, Print the ABS hot (for esun brand I used about 270 C) and turn off the cooling fan to maximize layer adhesion. There are no tricky overhangs to worry about. This was sized and made the way it was to fit on the bed of a Lulzbot Mini, which is just about 6 inch square.

Many thanks to Gael Langevin, the creator of the InMoov 3D-printed robot (http://www.inmoov.fr).
This post is a modification of the front skull, which originally consists of 4 parts. The goal was a continuous forehead. The 4 parts were put together, the surface was smoothed and then I made a transversal cut.
The holes on top where removed, because there are not needed anymore. The connectors were redesigned to also give support when printing.

title: Simple 608 bearing spool holder for Ultimachine spools

description.text: Just what the title says, this is a simple spool holder for Ultimachine (and possible other) spools.  Should work with any spool with a roughly 40 mm center hole.

Print two copies.  
The bearing recess is tight fit, you can warm the plastic to help press fit it in. 
With the two bearing in place, sandwich the spool between them and run a 8 mm (or 5/16") thread rod though the bearing.  Snug a nut on either side (not too tight).  I'd suggest another pair of nuts to lock the first two in place.
You can figure out a mount yourself, either hang it as I have done, mount one end of the thread rod to something, of set the rod across a stand of some kind.
Enjoy your nice, smooth turning, spool mount!

I needed AC power to feed to 220VAC heat bed and the DC +5, +12 and GND to feed my RAMPS1.4 and limit switches i came up with a solution.
I shall share a small video so that everybody knows the intent of design and its safe use. Two identical plugs/Sockets for AC and DC voltage shall be color coded/ tagged so that they can fit at the same location and no blue-smoke emerges due to wrongly putting 220VAC plug in DC socket. I am using ATX computer power supply to get +12DC +5VDC and GND. FOR DC plug, the top pin is GND , Left is +5VDC and Right is +12VDC. The socket and plug i shall both color RED and right down DC.
For AC... Top pin is connected to nothing, Left and Right is connected to Neutral and Live. I will just right down and tag it AC. Again the above picture shows non-live end, this box will be directly connected to the printer. If you remove the plugs and touch the pins of the socket (as shown in above picture ) you will find no current. And off course if the Power-supply is connected you can not touch the pins of Plug as it is female and you have no approach to touch
SAFETY:
The Picture shows the receiving end of 220V do not use it vice versa... The Plug that is not shown will carry 220V.

author: georgarloese

description.text: A Simple Holder that keeps the desk clean. It can hold a 13" Mac Book and any iPad. I have Made it big enough to hold them in there covers, it can hold the iPads in Otter box cases or most Leather covers. It has a base support structure that breaks off and then only a lite sand is required to provide a clean smooth finish. I added a cut out in the rear to hold a Apple TV remote. The front is cut out to allow access to the iPads home button and to avoid the standing putting pressure on the screen. It's simple and works and considering the ones available range from $69 - $190 a cheap alternative.

Firstly lay the holder down so that the Rectangle base is flat on the Platte, I dont know why but when I save it From Solidworks it is flat but in Makerware it is always on it's side. Dont even bother unless you have a Glass Platten. I used painters tape on the platten and purchased a new Hardened Glass platten from Bilby CNC. Every second print would lift at the corners so i developed a system that worked without fail. 1. Sand platten with 1200 grit paper and blow dust off. 2. level Platten using a sheet of paper and allow the tip to run over the paper and then adjust your leveling screws so that the paper only has the slightest drag on it. 3. Load filament for 30 seconds to preheat nozzle and clear old material. 4. Coat Platten with Acetone and allow to dry.
  • The most important step, I perform a print but stop it after the raft has been printed. I remove the raft and apply Selleys Quick Fix super glue to the corners of the model and to the 2 centre support strips. The glue takes about 10 mins to dry which allows the printer to get the raft down and the glue holds it in position. Since doing this I have not had one failed print. Only a thin layer is required and then start printing straight away. When printing use a raft as it will indicate if you have a good adhesion and it also helps with peeling. If you havent got the latest firmware get it as the rafts are greatly improved and extend outside the model to help with peeling. I have printed in .2mm and .1mm and had no issues. 2 shells and 10% fill and it will take about 6 hours. Peel of the platten slowly with a butter knife and break the supports off with pliers. Have fun and remember "The only way to predict the future is to make it!"

print_settings.Infill:: 3 Shells / 35% or more to make the finer features solid / strong

title: Mini Christmas Tree with hook on Decorations!

description.text:
The perfect mini Christmas tree for your desk, office or as a decoration around the house. 
This is printable with no support but the designed in support version is recommended to help ensure a good result. The support should be easily removed and acts to prevent the print from breaking away while printing the widest points of the branches. 
The pot and tree are all one piece. Use 3 shells and 35% infill to make the finer features strong. 
There are three different decorations you can print in your choice of colours. It's recommended to print the base of the decorations in the same colour filament as the tree (so the hook is not noticeable)  then pause the machine at 3mm / approx. 75% completed (with Raft On) and change the filament to the colour of choice for your decorations. Print as many as you like... they are very small and take next to no time to make. 
Print the top star separately in your choice of colour... no support required. 
Once printed just remove he raft and support then decorate your tree by hanging the decorations on the branches and place the star on top... this prints really well in PLA on Replicator 2's and 5th Generation Replicators.
At standard scale the total height including the star is approx. 100mm tall and is approx. 60mm round at the widest point. If you test a couple of decorations and find they are too tight to fit on the branches just scale them up approx. 5% to increase the size of the hole through them. 
A great little 3D printed multi-part Christmas decoration. This print has fine detail/clearances however most well set up, accurate, 3D printers should be able to print this well as the images show. 
Note: If you like this. check out all my other fun and practical designs... and post pictures of your decorated Christmas Trees!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard

Infill:

3 Shells / 35% or more to make the finer features solid / strong

Notes: I recommend using the designed in support file (A No Support stl has also been uploaded). The designed in support should be relatively easy to 'gently' break away from the lower branches. Use 3 shells and 35% plus infill to make the tree strong. 2 Shells and 35% infill is okay for the decorations and star. The prints shown in the pictures were all printed with PLA. The decorations should be a snug fit and, in some cases due to the branches being 'random placement (like a real tree) you may need to gently push a branch down to fit a decoration. If the decorations are too tight increase the X/Y scale approx. 5% to increase the hole size. Print the first approx. 3mm / 75% (with Raft On) of the decorations in the same colour as your tree then change colours to suit. The star has a hole in its base. No support is required. Once printed, and with the Raft removed, it should push onto the top of the tree approc. 5mm.
Just decorate it! Other than removing the Raft and designed in Support your mini Christmas Tree is ready to decorate...Merry Christmas!

remixed_from.author: ekidd
remixed_from.title: Webcam Mount for Printrbot Simple Metal Heated Bed

title: Fixed-yaw Raspberry Pi camera mount for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text: This is a mount for attaching a Raspberry Pi camera to the bed of your Simple Metal. The yaw is fixed so that the camera points exactly at the center of the bed. The pitch is adjustable so that you can aim the camera down towards the bed for small prints, or higher for tall prints. The rigidity of the this mount eliminates camera shake caused by bed travel, making your time lapse videos sharper. It was also designed to have a small footprint, so you can put your Simple Metal into the smallest enclosure possible like I do. It is also compatible with my Digital Thermometer Addon. Here's a demonstration video showing footage from this mount! I highly recommend that you use this mount and not my Tough RasPi Camera mount, for reasons explained in the How I Designed This section.

• 1x Bed mount from this project
  • 1x Camera case from this project
  • 1x caseBack.stl from Jerware's camera mount

• 2 × M3 screw
  • 2 × M3 nut
  • A small wide-angle lens designed to attach to a mobile phone. I used this sort of lens — note that the lens attaches to the clip via a loop that fits in a channel in the lens' base, and not via screw threads.
  • I strongly recommend a long RPi camera cable so that you have more flexibility in where you put the RPi itself.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height and 0.4 mm nozzle diam.

Infill:

10-20 %

Notes: I recommend not using a brim because it would fill up the nut trap holes on the underside of the bracket part, and then it would be a pain to dig out. The overhang of the attachment arm on the camera case is 65°, which is easily printable without supports for any well-maintained printer.

Defining the problem space and making a Specification After using my Tough RasPi Camera mount for a month I started noticing some shortcomings in it, most of them due to my choice to print parts of Jerware's camera mount in PLA:
  • Jerware used a swivel arm to pinch the camera case to maintain its pitch. If you print this arm in PLA like I did, it will relax over time and lose the ability to grip the camera.
  • Because it wouldn't grip the camera, the camera sort of flopped around.
  • Because the camera flopped around, it was hard to keep it level and pointing at the centre of the build plate.
  • Because I put the mounting arm at the front corner of the bracket, the camera poked out in front of the printer. Because my printer enclosure is only just large enough to fit the Simple Metal, the camera would often rub against the door and get dislodged from the position I set.
  • Because the mount was designed to be moveable (and because the plastic was relaxing), the camera image would shake a little whenever the bed moved. This made time-lapse videos a bit blurry.
    • The specification for this object was therefore:
  • MUST hold the camera at a fixed angle and height, appropriate for my wide-angle lens.
    • The redesign in July 2016 added adjustable pitch. Even though I can't aim the camera any more, this isn't actually a loss. I found that I always wanted to set the camera in the same way for every print: pointing towards the center and held completely level so that the wide-angle lens could capture the whole build volume from top to bottom.
  • MUST protrude as little as possible from the edges of the bed.
    • MUST not be so far inside the bed that it interferes with the bed levelling process.
  • SHOULD resist camera shake from bed movement.
    • Let's go! Highlights of the build There isn't much to say about this one because it's really just a remix of my old mount and Jerware's camera case. I'll share some of the interesting problems I solved for it: Finding the correct angle for the camera case was a bit tricky. I eventually did it by grabbing a feeler gauge, putting the hinge on the location where the mounting post would be, pointing a feeler leaf at the centre of the bed, and just measuring the angle between the leaf and handle with a protractor. I wanted to angle the camera a little bit downwards so that I was looking more at the center of the build plate. Instead of inclining the holding arm by 5°m which is an angle that requires support to print successfully, I simply angled the holes inside the arm. I'm actually getting super good at judging tolerances for holes now. My go-to figure is +0.4 mm OD, so where I wanted to put a 3 mm hole in this model, I've actually made it 3.4 mm. I did the same thing for the holes to accept the M3 nuts, and I was so gratified when the nuts fit in perfectly. So for future readers:
  • 0.0 mm tolerance: Will not fit.
  • 0.2 mm tolerance: Will not fit. The parts can be driven together with a hammer, but you are likely to crack or split the receiving part.
  • 0.3 mm tolerance: Tight fit. The parts can be hammered together with only a little bit of deformation.
  • 0.4 mm tolerance: Perfect fit. You may need to clean up some burrs or elephant's feet, but the holes should be properly-sized.
  • 0.6 mm tolerance: Loosey-goosey.

12 Jul 2016
  • Redesigned camera case.stl to add adjustable pitch to the camera.
  • Removed vestigial holes from Jerware's old camera case design.
  • Resized the lens mounting hole to fit the (new) recommended lens.
    • 23 Nov 2015
  • Initial release.
    • Tinkercad source document is here.

author: temrose

title: Sports windshield spoiler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A manually-adjustable, non-destructively-attachable deflector for  motorcycle windshield.  Clamp on trailing edge of motorcycle windshield and tilt it up/down to keep the turbulant air away from your helmet. Or steer it toward your helmet. If you prefer.

Modelled in Solidworks, sized to print on a TOM. Uses M3 bolts of 12 to 20mm lengths for assembly. Most bits printed with 2 shells and 30% infill. Uses thin rubber sheet or foam (or maybe Sugru?) to make the clamp jaws grippy. I recommend Nyloc nuts because motorcycles are high-vibration environments. Print:
1 centre wing
1 left wing
1 right wing
2 brackets (Mirror the second one in RepG) (1) Bolt the left and right wings to the centre wing panel.
(2) Bolt the brackets onto the left and right wings.
(3) The non-invasive clamps are a little tricky. The bolt through the rearmost holes should have two nuts between the jaws of the clamp. One nut is tightened up against the upper clamp arm. The other nut is used to push the opposite jaw DOWN.
(4) The frontmost holes have a bolt through them. One nut is used to pull the lower clamp arm toward the upper.
(5) Clamp jaws onto windshield with Sugru or thin foam-rubber or rubber sheet to protect (and engrippify) the windshield.
(6) Adjust angle as necessary to help steer the air coming off the windshield up/down to preference. I use this to keep the turbulant air away from my helmet, i.e. reduced wind noise and buffeting. Something like that.

title: Model Rocket with Firecracker Payload
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This rocket only takes one way trips.  Load in up to eight firecrackers that ignite using the exhaust from the model rocket engine, and hopefully explode at the peak of the rocket's flight.  The holes in the body are meant to be whistles similar to the whistles on a Nerf Vortex football.  I don't know how well they work yet because I have yet to launch my rocket.  
The rocket requires standard A, B, or C engines, and firecrackers that are 1/4" in diameter.

Print the rocket using a low infill and preferably 1 perimeter to limit the weight.  
Insert the firecrackers first, then slide in the model rocket engine.  If any of the firecrackers are loose, make sure you glue them in place to keep them from being left on the launch pad after takeoff.

14 mm tyre truck mold. PLEASE! do not use this or any other mine contribution to make money.

Thank you you want more designs?
Join the group and check out. bring your favorite designs!
@ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/scalemodels/things If this thing was helpful or you like the designs, please click the "like" button. in that way I will continue sharing more things. If you print one I would love to see it in the section "i made one"
of course, all views and advice are welcomed, you can always improve design.. thanks for watching

This thing is a clip to allow the camera of a SYMA X5SC quadcopter to be mounted horizontaly.
It makes reuse of the original clip (that stays in place on the camera module) and will clip back to the quadcopter, lowering the back of the camera approximatively 5mm so it can now look straight forward instead of looking down.

No

comments.text: I am afraid the scale of the STL files is not correct. They turn out extremely small when I try to print them out after slicing them with CURA. author: PCFlyer

description.text:
This Lulzbot Taz 5 Spoolholder is made with uStix and is an alternative to the original one that hangs on the side of the machine. This spoolholder can be placed in the grooves of the aluminium beams on top of the machine You need to print:
• 1 x Spoolholder
• 2 x Spoolbolt Simply assemble the three parts, you shouldn't encounter any problems. uStix is a modular system with parts that all have the same threading. The thread is very large so there is quite some tolerances for different machines. As always, wasting material is not necessary, so it is designed in a way that you won't need any support material.
3D Print this one and show yours!
